response.answer_text: Majority and strong opinion of scholars of quran and sunnah is that anything which is accompanied by Music is haraam. Allaah says in Soorat Luqmaan (interpretation of the meaning): “And of mankind is he who purchases idle talks (i.e. music, singing) to mislead (men) from the path of Allaah…” [Luqmaan 31:6] The scholar of the ummah, Ibn ‘Abbaas (may Allaah be pleased with him) said: this means singing. Mujaahid (may Allaah have mercy on him) said: this means playing the drum (tabl). (Tafseer al-Tabari, 21/40). The Messenger of Allaah (peace and blessings of Allaah be upon him) said: “Among my ummah there will certainly be people who permit zinaa, silk, alcohol and musical instruments…” (Narrated by al-Bukhaari ta’leeqan, no. 5590; narrated as mawsool by al-Tabaraani and al-Bayhaqi. See al-Silsilah al-Saheehah by al-Albaani, 91. Look where music instrument has its place.! The Instrument of Daff is the only exception at the days of Eid and other important celebration as indicated by some narrations. Important thing to be noted is that it is permissible only to WOMEN. For men it is Haraam. Also as a general rule,In Islam anything which is amusement or Timepass which moves you away from the remembrance of Allah is Haraam. Allaah says (interpretation of the meaning): “Do you then wonder at this recitation (the Qur’aan)? And you laugh at it and weep not, Wasting your (precious) lifetime in pastime and amusements(music and singing) ” [al-Najm 53:59-61] Singing without Music. As for singing or humming a few (poetic) verses in which there is praise of Allaah or commending some good characteristics and other good meanings, the basic principle is that poetry is words; if the words are good it is good and if they are bad it is bad. So if the words are free of any bid’ah or exaggeration that is condemned by sharee’ah, and it is free of any bad or ugly words that are inappropriate and should not be said of Allaah, then it is acceptable to sing such things occasionally, on condition that it is not done in the manner of singers and promiscuous people (those immoral singers and their songs which romantizes adultry,alcoholism, exhibitionism etc), because that is imitating people of immorality and sin (“and whoever imitates a people is one of them”). Hating those singers for the sake of Allaah implies that we should not resemble them or imitate their style of singing. The believer should glorify and venerate Allaah by reciting aayahs from the Qur’aan and dhikr as prescribed in sharee’ah, and du’aa’s narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allaah be upon him) If he occasionally recites some verses of poetry which praise Allaah and mention His blessings and bounty, there is nothing wrong with that so long as they meet the conditions mentioned above. Hence Singing any poetry without music which makes you to remember Allah is fine and anything which makes you forget Allah and dwell upon worldly pleasures is Haraam. And Allaah knows best. Sources: Ruling on music, singing and dancing Is it correct to sing some songs without musical accompaniment?

Sure they can! but they have to avoid Ghina: Ghina is the type of song that is branded for amusement gatherings and parties.Ghina is related to the type of song; meaning that if the lyrics of a song convey positive messages to the listener but the music of the song is jaunty, it makes that music forbidden (Haram) [6].Ghina is when the lyrics of a song are about describing the beauties of a woman (whether physical or erotic description), or it has been written about wine, or dance or other prohibited (Haram) things in Islam [7].Ghina is any song that changes the mood of the listener; makes him/her either happy or sad; any music or song that makes a gap between the present moods of the listener with his/her “real self” and weakens the control of the person over her speech or behavior.Ghina is the sort of song that has such hopeless content, which destroys positive motivations of the listener.Ghina is any kind of song that by content, lyrics, or the specific sound of the musical instrument can arouse sexual temptation.for more information read: Are Muslims allowed to sing? www.salamislam.com

Singing is allowed--it is completely helal. There are far too many ultra conservatives today claiming that singing is haram--let alone music--but even music is helal. Most hadiths i have heard on music are not from reputable sources. And when the Prophet (savs) came to Medine he was welcomed with music and singing. The music they played is now even famous within the Islamic world, known as Tela El-Badru Eleyna. There is certainly debate on whether music is haram or helal within the Ummet. But the fact stands, from my viewpoint and the viewpoint of most Sunni and Shia schools that as long as the music does not depict something Haram, and expresses something poignant about the Human condition or glorifies Allah (svt) then it is perfectly permissible. I'm providing a link of all the Hadiths proving Music is helal below. Check them out. Hope that helps.

The general ruling on all things haram is - what is the purpose of the action. If it has a clearly positive outcome it’s usually allowed. If the end result is beneficial then it may be allowed. So the recommended reason or time for singing would be to incorporate that into a prayer of some kind or dedicate it to The One God, dedicate the lyrics to Islam and have the intention of increasing yours, or others, faith. Although some ultra-traditional conservative Imams may rule it as pointless and ban it entirely, it depends on the region and culture where that sect or flavor of Islam is taught. And, ultimately, it depends on what is said in the Quran, as the Quran cannot be contradicted so any verse regarding singing should be the official ruling despite any fatwas issued. And if it’s not mentioned in the Quran - then read different viewpoints on the subject and listen to your heart, it should be between you and God whether or not singing is beneficial.

For instance, Ghinā is a kind of singing accompanied by vocal undulation and rapture so that it is suitable for gatherings of lahw and sin. It is Haram for a singer to sing [ghina] and the listener to listen to it. (source: goo.gl/15duCV)

Simple Quranic Evidence States: “And of mankind is he who purchases idle talks (i.e., music, singing, etc.) to mislead (men) from the Path of Allah without knowledge, and takes it (the Path of Allah, or the Verses of the Qur’an) by way of mockery. For such there will be a humiliating torment (in the Hell-fire)” (31:6) You can easily read that any type of entertainment that misleads a person from practicing islam is forbidden for him. And it’s worse to speak out of knowledge and choose to enjoy forbidden content over the Quran.
